Description: A full-length view of a bearded Graeco-Egyptian mummy; arms by his side; the skin blackened and shrivelled; the stomach and eyes sunken; remnants of gilding still adhering in parts; numerous sketches to the verso, comprising mummified animals such as crocodiles, jackals, bulls, fish and cats; ships sailing on water; grotesque heads; the word 'LAMP'; and a seated Egyptian god with the head of a baboon (possibly Thoth?); illustration to Pettigrew's "A History of Egyptian Mummies and an Acount of the Worship and Embalming of the Sacred Animals by the Egyptians" (1834) Aquatint
Curator's comments: The sketches to the reverse are preparatory sketches for another print in the series, the description of which may be found at 1978, U.1133
Bibliographic references: Reid 1871 / A descriptive catalogue of the works of George Cruikshank (1622)
Associated titles: A History of Egyptian Mummies and an Acount of the Worship and Embalming of the Sacred Animals by the Egyptians
